title: Add DC-ASGD optimizer
body:
1. according to paper "Asynchronous Stochastic Gradient Descent with Delay Compensation for
   Distributed Deep Learning", DC-ASGD nearly approaches the performance of sequential SGD,  
   so implement it. 
2. add "--optimizer" argument in train_minst.py.
3. change metrics to "accuracy"

test train_minst with dockers in same machine.

11 dockers 11 workers bsp sgd with lr 0.1

body:
Hi @piiswrong ,

This is the patch set for high performance (>100% increase) v.s. the early one which support MKL chunk pass between layers. It can be turned on/off when setting USE_MKL2017_EXPERIMENTAL in config.mk. Pls kindly review.

Thanks

title: Learning curve charts in notebook live updated during training
body:
New model training callbacks PandasLogger and LiveLearningCurve.
PandasLogger builds a Dataframe with all training metrics.
LiveLearningCurve renders a chart in a notebook that updates live during training.
A little refactoring of callbacks from model.fit() to clean up and make this possible.

title: MKL2017 implemented layers integration to improve IA perf. on mxnet
body:
Hi @piiswrong , 

Pls review the latest MKL2017 implemented layers patches including conv, relu, lrn, batch-norm, concat, elementwise-sum, pooling and fc (total 8 layers). PR#3458 related code is merged into this. This version is putting MKL buffer inside layers and do conversion for input and output. Once your review is done, I will submit another PR to provide much higher perf. patch to pass MKL buffer between layers. 

Pls kindly review ASAP. 

Thanks

title: Crop assign
body:
Depends on https://github.com/dmlc/mshadow/pull/172

Added a `_crop_assign` op to replace legacy `_copy_slice_to` and `_assign_slice_from` operators.

I did not expose this to `__setitem__` and `__getitem__` as this will make copy, while our existing get item functions shares memory.

@piiswrong

title: Revamped tutorials and API reference pages. Adding examples from mxnet repo to tutorials sections
body:
**Tutorials**
- Pulled in examples from MXNet repo (mxnet/examples) and added to tutorials organized under application type. Example Computer Vision, NLP etc. Refer here for more details - https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/3504
- Moved Tutorials from various locations like How To, API reference pages to Tutorials page so that all tutorials can be found in one place.
- Segregated Tutorials as Python Tutorials and R Tutorials. 
- With this change users will now be able to easily find and follow all tutorials in one page.

**API Reference**
- Move tutorials to tutorials page. Cleaned up pages to have only content related to API references
- For C++ API references added links to doxygen (namespaces, classes, files)

**Broken Links**
- All references in MXNet docs will now point to http://mxnet.io instead of http://mxnet.readthedocs.io
- Fixed other broken links due to re-organization of contents.

**Others**
- Added recommended steps to help users logically traverse across docs when he reads.

title: Doc
body:
Ref #3504

Add doctest support for symbols (operators). Executing `test/python/doctest/run.py` will run the doctest. Currently we have infrastructure and examples for operator doctest. We may plan to add similar thing to NDArray operators if necessary (we might not need to because many of the operators are the same).
### Guidelines
- Language agnostic descriptions should go to the c++ files where the operators are registered. So that the description is available to all language bindings.
- Python-specific doc and examples are attached to each operator by deriving a subclass (e.g. `FullyConnectedDoc`) from `SymbolDoc`. Other languages bindings could probably do similar things.

The doctest should contains **Examples** and **Regression Test**.
- Examples: simple snippet showing how to use this operator in typical cases. For example, `SoftmaxOutput` should show a scenario for the default mode and a `multi_output` mode. I think the users mostly cares about the syntax of the call, name of the common parameters and maybe the resulting input / output shapes.
- Regression test: complete numerical test for the correctness of the operator. We are not expecting the user to read those, but to make sure our operator does not accidentally breaks. Typically one can compare to a numpy implementation of the op, or if the op is super complicated, hand craft special cases for expected outputs.
- Gradient check: we might want to add infrastructures to perform numerical gradient check for each operators as part of the regression test.

title: Time major data layout support for RNN
body:
Time major for the simple cuDNN RNN-cell demo on ptb runs 1.5~2 times faster than our original batch major layout.

``` text
# -- This script (time major) -----
#2016-10-10 18:43:21,890 Epoch[0] Batch [50]     Speed: 1717.76 samples/sec      Train-Perplexity=4311.345018
#2016-10-10 18:43:25,959 Epoch[0] Batch [100]    Speed: 1573.17 samples/sec      Train-Perplexity=844.092421
#2016-10-10 18:43:29,807 Epoch[0] Batch [150]    Speed: 1663.17 samples/sec      Train-Perplexity=498.080716
#2016-10-10 18:43:33,871 Epoch[0] Batch [200]    Speed: 1574.84 samples/sec      Train-Perplexity=455.051252
#2016-10-10 18:43:37,720 Epoch[0] Batch [250]    Speed: 1662.87 samples/sec      Train-Perplexity=410.500066
#2016-10-10 18:43:40,766 Epoch[0] Batch [300]    Speed: 2100.81 samples/sec      Train-Perplexity=274.317460
#2016-10-10 18:43:44,571 Epoch[0] Batch [350]    Speed: 1682.45 samples/sec      Train-Perplexity=350.132577
#2016-10-10 18:43:48,377 Epoch[0] Batch [400]    Speed: 1681.41 samples/sec      Train-Perplexity=320.674884
#2016-10-10 18:43:51,253 Epoch[0] Train-Perplexity=336.210212
#2016-10-10 18:43:51,253 Epoch[0] Time cost=33.529
#2016-10-10 18:43:53,373 Epoch[0] Validation-Perplexity=282.453883
#
# -- ../rnn/rnn_cell_demo.py (batch major) -----
#2016-10-10 18:44:34,133 Epoch[0] Batch [50]     Speed: 1004.50 samples/sec      Train-Perplexity=4398.428571
#2016-10-10 18:44:39,874 Epoch[0] Batch [100]    Speed: 1114.85 samples/sec      Train-Perplexity=771.401960
#2016-10-10 18:44:45,528 Epoch[0] Batch [150]    Speed: 1132.03 samples/sec      Train-Perplexity=525.207444
#2016-10-10 18:44:51,564 Epoch[0] Batch [200]    Speed: 1060.37 samples/sec      Train-Perplexity=453.741140
#2016-10-10 18:44:57,865 Epoch[0] Batch [250]    Speed: 1015.78 samples/sec      Train-Perplexity=411.914237
#2016-10-10 18:45:04,032 Epoch[0] Batch [300]    Speed: 1037.92 samples/sec      Train-Perplexity=381.302188
#2016-10-10 18:45:10,153 Epoch[0] Batch [350]    Speed: 1045.49 samples/sec      Train-Perplexity=363.326871
#2016-10-10 18:45:16,062 Epoch[0] Batch [400]    Speed: 1083.21 samples/sec      Train-Perplexity=377.929014
#2016-10-10 18:45:19,993 Epoch[0] Train-Perplexity=294.675899
#2016-10-10 18:45:19,993 Epoch[0] Time cost=52.604
#2016-10-10 18:45:21,401 Epoch[0] Validation-Perplexity=294.345659
```

Data layout is achieved via a `LayoutMapper` that decides which dimension is treated as the `batch` axis separately for each input data, label, and output blob. This is because hybrid data layout might be needed. For example, some of our RNN related ops now take `seq_len` as input. The `seq_len` will be a 1D tensor, therefore in batch-major, while the rest of the data for RNN will be in time-major. Currently the default layout mapper will decide the layout according to the name postfix. But the user can define their own layout mapper with a lookup table if needed.

@piiswrong I tried the `crop` and `slice_axis` NDArray operator, but they do not work for this case as we need to (potentially) copy data from one device to another. So I'm keeping the current copy_slice_to and assign_slice_from functions.

@antinucleon I think by default, the RNN IO should output time-major for efficiency. I also fixed the softmax out by added another mode (`preserve_shape`). But I guess a unified `axis=` solution will be cleaner.

repo.name: mxnet
repo.description: Lightweight, Portable, Flexible Distributed/Mobile Deep Learning with Dynamic, Mutation-aware Dataflow Dep Scheduler; for Python, R, Julia, Scala, Go, Javascript and more

title: [faster-rcnn] Use executor.reshape for testing
body:
1. Use executor.reshape for testing.
   
   The original test function creates a new executor every minibatch, which is not so memory-efficient. This     PR uses `executor.reshape` to generate a new shared executor every minibatch. The inner-space of the executor will be upsized if a larger data-batch comes and no up-sizing is needed otherwise.
2. Fix format-string on Windows
   
   The previous format string  has some problems on Windows and this PR fixes it.
3. Add warmup
   
   `warmup.py` is missed for end2end training

@precedenceguo @winstywang @tornadomeet

title: [EXEC] Enable inplace sum optimization
body:
@antinucleon @piiswrong

Also other fixes in this PR, the optimization will trigger when sum of gradients takes inputs larger than MXNET_EXEC_INPLACE_GRAD_SUM_CAP
-  identity function now do not compute during WriteInplace
- CUDNN convolution can take kAddTo correctly for both forward and backward.

This optimization requires ops involved to implement kAddTo requirement correctly. I find some ops are sloppy at this case. Currently it is an opt out strategy and assumes every op support kAddTo by default. I am wondering if it is safer to choose an opt in strategy. 

i.e. add an attribute to ask each operator declare if they support kAddTo correctly and the optimization only triggers for those ops that does

repo.name: mxnet
repo.description: Lightweight, Portable, Flexible Distributed/Mobile Deep Learning with Dynamic, Mutation-aware Dataflow Dep Scheduler; for Python, R, Julia, Scala, Go, Javascript and more

title: Stochastic Depth Training
body:
Simple implementation of Stochastic Depth Training with the Module API. I did not use fancy tricks like constant graph and re-pointing weights, because the prediction needs to use all the layers anyway. The speed on a single GPU seem to be similar to [the torch implementation](https://github.com/yueatsprograms/Stochastic_Depth) (they report 60 seconds, while we are ~50 seconds, but my GPU might be better).

I did not observe good speedup by running multi-GPU, though. Maybe because of overhead of data copying between modules -- note each block is an independent module, so e.g. the 110-layer Resnet has 50+ modules.

I did not try to use the exact hyper parameters as the torch implementation. Both the residual block and the skip connections are also slightly different. Will add final number to the comments after finish running. The progress up to now seems reasonable:

```
INFO:root:Epoch[127] Batch [100]        Speed: 1056.31 samples/sec      Train-accuracy=0.961094
INFO:root:Epoch[127] Batch [150]        Speed: 1041.82 samples/sec      Train-accuracy=0.958438
INFO:root:Epoch[127] Batch [200]        Speed: 1044.29 samples/sec      Train-accuracy=0.949688
INFO:root:Epoch[127] Batch [250]        Speed: 1057.96 samples/sec      Train-accuracy=0.953906
INFO:root:Epoch[127] Batch [300]        Speed: 1054.22 samples/sec      Train-accuracy=0.955781
INFO:root:Epoch[127] Batch [350]        Speed: 1053.62 samples/sec      Train-accuracy=0.952031
INFO:root:Epoch[127] Train-accuracy=0.949920
INFO:root:Epoch[127] Time cost=47.548
INFO:root:Saved checkpoint to "sd-110-0128.params"
INFO:root:Epoch[127] Validation-accuracy=0.894131
```

title: MKLdnn Integration Patch to improve issue #2986(call for cpu performance)
body:
Hi, @piiswrong 

Mxnet's CPU performance is not as good as GPU's. 
please see #2986. @xmchen1987

This PR integrates MKLDNN into mxnet including all the major operations(conv, pool, lrn, bn and fc).
It turns out we can achieve 750+ fps for alexnet scoring and 280+ fps for Googlenet-v1 scoring with this patch in two-socket broadwell server and the backward also can benefit greatly from this patch. 

Please review the patches then give us feedbacks.
Thanks.

title: Feature/caffe importer improvements
body:
A few improvements:
- allows importing from prototxt definitions with Input layers (currently doesn't support this, and is most common case)
- add support for TanH and Sigmoid activations (needed by some Caffe model zoo nets, eg "Holistically-Nested Edge Detection")
- a mean image importer (import caffe mean image protobuf to NDArray)
- Some comments on the current incompatibility between the strided pooling output dims of MXNet and Caffe that is not dealt with by the importer (can be frustrating for users of the importer not to know about this issue).

title: Add {valid, full} option for Pooling layer
body:
Mxnet's pooling layer's output doesn't match Caffe's pooling's output, although Mxnet's convolution layer's output shape is same as Caffe. This issue will cause Googlenet from caffe convertor failing.

The following links shows pooling output size formula.
for caffe, 
https://github.com/BVLC/caffe/blob/master/src/caffe/layers/pooling_layer.cpp#L90
for mxnet, 
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/pooling-inl.h#L202

And please see #2999. @winstywang @ChenFengAndy

So I add two options for pooling layer {valid, same}. valid is for current mxnet's pooling output and for caffe, it uses same option
1) default pooling option is valid, same as current mxnet.
2) if model is from caffe, same option for pooling layer will be on.

Please give some comments. Thanks a lot.

title: [RELEASE] v0.8 Release (Last release before NNVM refactor
body:
Please help add in changes I missed.
## v0.8

This is the last release before the NNVM refactor.
- CaffeOp and CaffeIter for interfacing with Caffe by @HrWangChengdu @cjolivier01
- WrapCTC plugin for sequence learning by @xlvector
- Improved Multi-GPU performance by @mli
- CuDNN RNN support by @sbodenstein
- OpenCV plugin for parallel image IO by @piiswrong
- More operators as simple op
  - Simple OP @tqchen
  - element wise op with axis and broadcast @mli @sxjscience
- Cudnn auto tuning for faster convolution by @piiswrong
- More applications
  - Faster RCNN by @precedenceguo

title: disable SSE for arm hardware e.g. Raspberry Pi
body: SSE must be disabled on ARM hardware for the build to succeed. With these modifications I was able to build and use mxnet on an armhf CPU.
